steps.title: Understand acceleration.
steps.content: Understand acceleration. Acceleration describes how quickly something is speeding up or slowing down . [1] X Research source The concept really is that simple, although your math textbook might describe it as the "change in velocity over time." Acceleration also describes the direction something is moving, which you can include as a written description or as part of the math: Usually, if an object is accelerating right , up , or forward , people write it as a positive (+) number. If an object accelerates left , down , or backward , use a negative (-) number for acceleration instead.

steps.title: Write the definition as a formula.
steps.content: Write the definition as a formula. As mentioned above, acceleration is the change in velocity over the change in time . [2] X Expert Source Sean Alexander, MS Physics Tutor Expert Interview. 14 May 2020. [3] X Research source There are two ways to write this as a math formula: [4] X Research source a av = Δv / Δt (The symbol Δ or "delta" just means "change.") a av = (v f - v i ) / (t f - t i ) In this equation, v f is the final velocity, and v i is the initial, or starting, velocity

steps.title: Find the initial and final velocity of the object.
steps.content: Find the initial and final velocity of the object. For example, if a car goes from parked on the sidewalk to moving at a velocity of 500 meters/second to the right, the initial velocity is 0 m/s, and the final velocity is 500 m/s right. [5] X Research source From now on, we'll use positive numbers to describe motion to the right, so we don't have to specify the direction every time. If the car starts out going forward and ends up going backward, make sure to write the final velocity as a negative number.

steps.title: Note the change in time.
steps.content: Note the change in time. For instance, the car might take 10 seconds to reach the final velocity. Unless the problem says otherwise, this usually means t f = 10 seconds and t i = 0 seconds. [6] X Research source Make sure your velocities and times are written in consistent units. For instance, if your velocity is written in miles per hour, the time should be written in hours as well.

steps.title: Use these numbers to calculate average acceleration.
steps.content: Use these numbers to calculate average acceleration. Put the velocities and time into the formula to find the average acceleration. [7] X Research source In our example: a av = (500 m/s - 0 m/s) / (10s - 0s) a av = (500 m/s) / (10 s) a av = 50 m / s / s This can also be written as 50 m/s 2 .

steps.title: Understand the result.
steps.content: Understand the result. The average acceleration describes how rapidly the velocity changed during the time we're examining, on average. [8] X Research source In the example above, the car was speeding up to the right, and each second it sped up by an average of 50 m/s. Note that the details of the exact movement can change, as long as the car ends up with the same total change in velocity and change in time: The car could start at 0 m/s and accelerates at a constant rate for 10 seconds, until it reaches 500 m/s. The car could start at 0 m/s, accelerate rapidly to 900 m/s, then slow down to 500 m/s by the 10th second. The car could start at 0 m/s, stay still for 9 seconds, then jump to 500 m/s very rapidly in the 10th second.

steps.title: Know what positive and negative velocity represents.
steps.content: Know what positive and negative velocity represents. Although velocity always specifies a direction, it can be tedious to keep writing "up" or "north" or "toward the wall." Instead, most math problems will assume the object is moving along a straight line. Moving in one direction on this line gets described as a positive (+) velocity, and movement in the other direction is negative (-) velocity. [9] X Research source For example, a blue train is moving east at 500 m/s. A red train is moving west equally fast, but since it is in the opposite direction, it is traveling at -500 m/s instead.

steps.title: Use the definition of acceleration to determine + or - signs.
steps.content: Use the definition of acceleration to determine + or - signs. Acceleration is the change in velocity over time. [10] X Research source If you're confused about whether to write acceleration as positive or negative, check the change in velocity and see what comes out: v final - v initial = + or - ?

steps.title: Understand speeding up in each direction.
steps.content: Understand speeding up in each direction. Let's say a blue train and a red train move away from each other with a speed of 5 m/s. We can picture these on a number line, with the blue train moving at +5 m/s along the positive side of the number line, and the red train moving at -5 m/s along the negative side. If each train starts to accelerate until it reaches 2 m/s faster in the direction it is moving, does each train have positive or negative acceleration? [11] X Research source Let's check: The blue train is moving faster along the positive side, so it's increasing from +5 m/s to +7 m/s. The final velocity minus the initial velocity is 7 - 5 = +2. Since the change in velocity is positive, so is the acceleration. The red train is moving faster along the negative side, so it starts out -5 m/s but ends up going -7 m/s. The final velocity minus the initial velocity is -7 - (-5) = -7 + 5 = -2 m/s. Since the change in velocity is negative, so is the acceleration.

steps.title: Understand slowing down.
steps.content: Understand slowing down. [12] X Research source Let's say a plane starts out traveling at 500 miles per hour, but then slows down to 400 miles per hour. Although it's still moving in a positive or forward direction, the plane's acceleration was negative, because it's moving less quickly forward than before. You can check this the same way as the examples above: 400 - 500 = -100, so the acceleration is negative. [13] X Research source Meanwhile, if a helicopter is moving -100 miles per hour and accelerates to -50 miles per hour, it has experienced positive acceleration. This is because the change in velocity was in the positive direction: -50 - (-100) = +50, even though the change was not enough to reverse the helicopter's direction.
